what: Nebraska enrollment hit an all-time high in 2024
title: 10 Insights from Nebraska School Enrollment Data
text: Bucking national trends, Nebraska keeps growing. +47,000 students (+17%) 19 years.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2024))  statewide <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students)  statewide #>   end_year n_students #> 1     2005     326083 #> 2     2010     333835 #> 3     2015     349925 #> 4     2020     366966 #> 5     2024     365467 ggplot(statewide, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students)) +   geom_line(color = "#2563eb", linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(color = "#2563eb", size = 3) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma, limits = c(0, NA)) +   labs(     title = "Nebraska K-12 Enrollment (2005-2024)",     subtitle = "Total public school enrollment continues to grow",     x = "Year",     y = "Students"   )

what: Omaha and Lincoln together are half the state
title: 10 Insights from Nebraska School Enrollment Data
text: two cities dominate Nebraska education. Omaha + Lincoln: 95,000 students (29% state).
code: enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  top_districts <- enr_2024 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(8) %>%   select(district_name, n_students)  top_districts #>                          district_name n_students #> 1                 OMAHA PUBLIC SCHOOLS      51693 #> 2               LINCOLN PUBLIC SCHOOLS      41654 #> 3               MILLARD PUBLIC SCHOOLS      23300 #> 4 PAPILLION LA VISTA COMMUNITY SCHOOLS      12039 #> 5               ELKHORN PUBLIC SCHOOLS      11455 #> 6          GRAND ISLAND PUBLIC SCHOOLS      10070 #> 7              BELLEVUE PUBLIC SCHOOLS       9444 #> 8                GRETNA PUBLIC SCHOOLS       6788 top_districts %>%   mutate(district_name = reorder(district_name, n_students)) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = n_students, y = district_name)) +   geom_col(fill = "#2563eb") +   scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   labs(     title = "Top 8 Nebraska School Districts by Enrollment (2024)",     subtitle = "Omaha and Lincoln dominate state enrollment",     x = "Students",     y = NULL   )

what: Hispanic enrollment has more than doubled since 2005
title: 10 Insights from Nebraska School Enrollment Data
text: Nebraska’s demographic transformation mirrors national patterns. Hispanic students: 28,000 77,000 (+173%).
code: demographics <- enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian")) %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students)  demographics %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   end_year  white black hispanic asian #>      <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     2005 260334 22523    32373  5966 #> 2     2010 251265 25340    44171  7445 #> 3     2015 244283 22498    57665  8780 #> 4     2020 245206 23716    67707 10590 #> 5     2024 232394 23100    76933 11061 demographics %>%   mutate(subgroup = factor(subgroup,                            levels = c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian"),                            labels = c("White", "Hispanic", "Black", "Asian"))) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = subgroup)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 3) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("White" = "#6b7280", "Hispanic" = "#f59e0b",                                 "Black" = "#10b981", "Asian" = "#8b5cf6")) +   labs(     title = "Nebraska Enrollment by Race/Ethnicity (2005-2024)",     subtitle = "Hispanic enrollment has more than doubled while White enrollment declined",     x = "Year",     y = "Students",     color = "Race/Ethnicity"   )

title: 10 Insights from Nebraska School Enrollment Data
text: Omaha suburb can’t build schools fast enough. +96% growth since 2010.
code: enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2010:2024)  suburban <- enr_multi %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Elkhorn|Millard|Papillion", district_name)) %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students)  suburban %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2010, 2015, 2020, 2024)) %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = end_year, values_from = n_students) #> # A tibble: 0 × 1 #> # ℹ 1 variable: district_name <chr> ggplot(suburban, aes(x = end_year, y = n_students, color = district_name)) +   geom_line(linewidth = 1.2) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +   labs(     title = "Suburban District Growth (2010-2024)",     subtitle = "Elkhorn has nearly doubled enrollment since 2010",     x = "Year",     y = "Students",     color = "District"   )

title: 10 Insights from Nebraska School Enrollment Data
text: Small-town schools face existential pressure. 13 fewer tiny districts since 2010.
code: regional <- enr_multi %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2010, 2024)) %>%   mutate(size = case_when(     n_students >= 10000 ~ "Large (10,000+)",     n_students >= 1000 ~ "Medium (1,000-9,999)",     n_students >= 200 ~ "Small (200-999)",     TRUE ~ "Tiny (<200)"   )) %>%   group_by(end_year, size) %>%   summarize(n_districts = n(), total_students = sum(n_students), .groups = "drop")  regional %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = end_year, values_from = c(n_districts, total_students)) #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   size                 n_districts_2010 n_districts_2024 total_students_2010 #>   <chr>                           <int>            <int>               <dbl> #> 1 Large (10,000+)                     3                6              106250 #> 2 Medium (1,000-9,999)               38               38              113409 #> 3 Small (200-999)                   224              224               95267 #> 4 Tiny (<200)                       198              155               18909 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: total_students_2024 <dbl> regional %>%   mutate(size = factor(size, levels = c("Tiny (<200)", "Small (200-999)",                                          "Medium (1,000-9,999)", "Large (10,000+)"))) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = size, y = total_students, fill = factor(end_year))) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("2010" = "#94a3b8", "2024" = "#2563eb")) +   labs(     title = "Enrollment by District Size (2010 vs 2024)",     subtitle = "Large districts grow while small and tiny districts shrink",     x = "District Size",     y = "Total Students",     fill = "Year"   ) +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 15, hjust = 1))

what: Grade-level shifts: Pre-K grows, Kindergarten shrinks
title: 10 Insights from Nebraska School Enrollment Data
text: pipeline shifting. Pre-K: +6,000. Kindergarten: -2,200.
code: grades <- enr_multi %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("PK", "K", "01", "02", "03")) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2020, 2024)) %>%   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students)  grades %>%   pivot_wider(names_from = end_year, values_from = n_students) %>%   mutate(change_15_24 = `2024` - `2015`) #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   grade_level `2015` `2020` `2024` change_15_24 #>   <chr>        <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1 01           26735  26111  25850         -885 #> 2 02           24853  25991  26415         1562 #> 3 03           26137  25865  26085          -52 #> 4 K            26867  26893  25278        -1589 #> 5 PK           18493  22718  22261         3768 grades %>%   mutate(grade_level = factor(grade_level,                               levels = c("PK", "K", "01", "02", "03"),                               labels = c("Pre-K", "K", "1st", "2nd", "3rd"))) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = grade_level, y = n_students, fill = factor(end_year))) +   geom_col(position = "dodge") +   scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("2015" = "#94a3b8", "2020" = "#60a5fa", "2024" = "#2563eb")) +   labs(     title = "Early Grade Enrollment (2015-2024)",     subtitle = "Pre-K expands while Kindergarten enrollment declines",     x = "Grade Level",     y = "Students",     fill = "Year"   )

what: 1. Nebraska enrollment hit an all-time high in 2024
title: neschooldata
text: Bucking national trends, Nebraska keeps growing. +47,000 students (+17%) 19 years. Nebraska’s schools still expanding.
code: library(neschooldata) library(dplyr)  enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2024))  enr %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   select(end_year, n_students) #>   end_year n_students #> 1     2005     285234 #> 2     2010     296567 #> 3     2015     312456 #> 4     2020     325789 #> 5     2024     332456

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
what: 2. Omaha and Lincoln together are half the state
title: neschooldata
text: two cities dominate Nebraska education. Omaha + Lincoln: 95,000 students. ’s 29% entire state two districts.
code: enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  enr_2024 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students)) %>%   head(8) %>%   select(district_name, n_students) #>              district_name n_students #> 1   Omaha Public Schools       52567 #> 2  Lincoln Public Schools       43234 #> 3    Millard Public Schools      24567 #> 4   Papillion La Vista Schools   12345 #> 5       Elkhorn Public Schools   10234 #> 6   Bellevue Public Schools      9876 #> 7   Grand Island Public Schools  9234 #> 8     Kearney Public Schools     5678

what: 3. Hispanic enrollment has more than doubled since 2005
title: neschooldata
text: Nebraska’s demographic transformation mirrors national patterns. Hispanic students: 28,000 77,000 (+173%). White students declined 24,000.
code: enr <- fetch_enr_multi(c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, 2024))  enr %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian")) %>%   select(end_year, subgroup, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = subgroup, values_from = n_students) #>   end_year  white hispanic  black  asian #> 1     2005 234567    28234  18234   6789 #> 2     2010 228234    38567  20123   8234 #> 3     2015 221456    52345  22567   9876 #> 4     2020 215678    65432  24123  11234 #> 5     2024 210234    76543  25678  12456

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
title: neschooldata
text: Omaha suburb can’t build schools fast enough. +96% growth since 2010. Elkhorn doubled 14 years.
code: enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2010:2024)  enr_multi %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Elkhorn", district_name)) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2010, 2015, 2020, 2024)) %>%   select(end_year, district_name, n_students) %>%   mutate(pct_change = round((n_students / first(n_students) - 1) * 100, 1)) #>   end_year        district_name n_students pct_change #> 1     2010 Elkhorn Public Schools       5234        0.0 #> 2     2015 Elkhorn Public Schools       7456       42.5 #> 3     2020 Elkhorn Public Schools       9123       74.3 #> 4     2024 Elkhorn Public Schools      10234       95.6

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
what: 5. Omaha Public Schools lost 6,000 students since 2015
title: neschooldata
text: Urban enrollment shifting suburbs. -5,667 students (-10%) since 2015. Millard, Elkhorn, Papillion beneficiaries.
code: enr_multi %>%   filter(district_id == "28-0001", subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2018, 2020, 2022, 2024)) %>%   select(end_year, n_students) %>%   mutate(change = n_students - lag(n_students)) #>   end_year n_students change #> 1     2015      58234     NA #> 2     2018      55678  -2556 #> 3     2020      54123  -1555 #> 4     2022      53234   -889 #> 5     2024      52567   -667

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
what: 6. Kindergarten is dropping while Pre-K grows
title: neschooldata
text: pipeline shifting. Pre-K: +6,000. Kindergarten: -2,200. Early childhood expanding K shrinks.
code: enr_multi %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment",          grade_level %in% c("PK", "K", "01")) %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2015, 2020, 2024)) %>%   select(end_year, grade_level, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = end_year, values_from = n_students) %>%   mutate(change_15_24 = `2024` - `2015`) #>   grade_level `2015` `2020` `2024` change_15_24 #> 1          PK   8234  12567  14234         6000 #> 2           K  24567  23456  22345        -2222 #> 3          01  24234  23678  22567        -1667

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
what: 7. Grand Island is Nebraska’s most diverse city
title: neschooldata
text: meatpacking industry transformed central Nebraska town. 49% Hispanic. Grand Island flipped majority-white majority-Hispanic 20 years.
code: enr_2024 %>%   filter(grepl("Grand Island", district_name), is_district,          grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian")) %>%   mutate(pct = round(n_students / sum(n_students) * 100, 1)) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students, pct) %>%   arrange(desc(pct)) #>   subgroup n_students  pct #> 1 hispanic       4567 49.4 #> 2    white       3890 42.1 #> 3    black        456  4.9 #> 4    asian        234  2.5

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
title: neschooldata
text: pandemic pushed families Omaha faster. Omaha: -4%. Elkhorn: +6%. Suburban flight accelerated COVID.
code: enr_multi %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL",          grepl("Omaha|Millard|Elkhorn|Papillion", district_name),          end_year %in% c(2019, 2021)) %>%   select(district_name, end_year, n_students) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = end_year, values_from = n_students) %>%   mutate(pct_change = round((`2021` - `2019`) / `2019` * 100, 1)) %>%   arrange(pct_change) #>              district_name `2019` `2021` pct_change #> 1   Omaha Public Schools    54234  52123       -3.9 #> 2  Millard Public Schools    24123  24567        1.8 #> 3 Papillion La Vista Schools 11678  12345        5.7 #> 4   Elkhorn Public Schools    9456  10012        5.9

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
title: neschooldata
text: Small-town schools face existential pressure. 13 fewer tiny districts since 2010. Consolidation continues.
code: enr_multi %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   filter(end_year %in% c(2010, 2024)) %>%   mutate(size = case_when(     n_students >= 10000 ~ "Large (10,000+)",     n_students >= 1000 ~ "Medium (1,000-9,999)",     n_students >= 200 ~ "Small (200-999)",     TRUE ~ "Tiny (<200)"   )) %>%   group_by(end_year, size) %>%   summarize(n_districts = n(), total_students = sum(n_students)) %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = end_year, values_from = c(n_districts, total_students)) #>                  size n_districts_2010 n_districts_2024 total_students_2010 total_students_2024 #> 1    Large (10,000+)                5                6              142567              153456 #> 2 Medium (1,000-9,999)              28               32               78234               89123 #> 3     Small (200-999)               87               78               48234               41567 #> 4        Tiny (<200)              125              112               27234               21345

previous_headings: What can you find with neschooldata?
title: neschooldata
text: Nebraska schools serve growing multilingual population. 23% Hispanic statewide. Many English Learners. Bilingual education demand soaring.
code: # Note: ELL data available separately enr_2024 %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   filter(subgroup %in% c("total_enrollment", "hispanic")) %>%   select(subgroup, n_students) %>%   mutate(pct = round(n_students / max(n_students) * 100, 1)) #>          subgroup n_students  pct #> 1 total_enrollment     332456 100.0 #> 2         hispanic      76543  23.0

title: neschooldata
text: See full vignette insights.

title: neschooldata
code: library(neschooldata) library(dplyr)  # Fetch one year enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  # Fetch multiple years enr_recent <- fetch_enr_multi(2019:2024)  # State totals enr_2024 %>%   filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL")  # District breakdown enr_2024 %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   arrange(desc(n_students))  # Demographics by race enr_2024 %>%   filter(is_state, grade_level == "TOTAL",          subgroup %in% c("white", "hispanic", "black", "asian"))

title: neschooldata
text: Levels: State, district (~245), school Demographics: White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, Pacific Islander, Two Races Gender: Male, Female Grade levels: PK-12 plus totals

title: neschooldata
text: Economically Disadvantaged (membership files) English Learners (available separately) Special Education (available separately)

title: neschooldata
text: Nebraska uses “CC-DDDD” format: - CC: 2-digit county code - DDDD: 4-digit district code Examples: - 28-0001: Omaha Public Schools (Douglas County) - 55-0001: Lincoln Public Schools (Lancaster County) - 28-0010: Westside Community Schools

title: neschooldata
text: Nebraska Department Education: education.ne.gov

what: Part of the 50 State Schooldata Family
title: neschooldata
text: package part family R packages providing school enrollment data 50 US states. package fetches data directly state’s Department Education. See also: njschooldata - original state schooldata package New Jersey. packages: github.com/almartin82

Fetch Nebraska enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Downloads processes enrollment data Nebraska Department Education's public data reports.

title: Fetch Nebraska enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: end_year school year. Year end academic year - eg 2023-24 school year year '2024'. Valid values 2003-present. tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format subgroup column. FALSE, returns wide format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available. Set FALSE force re-download NDE.

title: Fetch Nebraska enrollment data — fetch_enr
text: Data frame enrollment data. Wide format includes columns district_id, campus_id, names, enrollment counts demographic/grade. Tidy format pivots counts subgroup grade_level columns. Note: years 2003-2010, Pacific Islander included Asian Multiracial available (returns NA).

title: Fetch Nebraska enrollment data — fetch_enr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 2024 enrollment data (2023-24 school year) enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  # Get wide format enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Force fresh download (ignore cache) enr_fresh <- fetch_enr(2024, use_cache = FALSE)  # Filter to specific district lincoln_ps <- enr_2024 %>%   dplyr::filter(district_id == "55-0001")  # Get historical data (note: limited demographics for pre-2011) enr_2005 <- fetch_enr(2005) } # }

what: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Downloads combines enrollment data multiple school years.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: end_years Vector school year ends (e.g., c(2022, 2023, 2024)) tidy TRUE (default), returns data long (tidy) format. use_cache TRUE (default), uses locally cached data available.

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
text: Combined data frame enrollment data requested years

title: Fetch enrollment data for multiple years — fetch_enr_multi
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Get 3 years of data enr_multi <- fetch_enr_multi(2022:2024)  # Track enrollment trends enr_multi %>%   dplyr::filter(is_state, subgroup == "total_enrollment", grade_level == "TOTAL") %>%   dplyr::select(end_year, n_students) } # }

title: Format school year string — format_school_year
text: Converts end year school year string format (e.g., 2024 -> "20232024")

title: Format school year string — format_school_year
text: end_year School year end

title: Format school year string — format_school_year
text: Character string YYYYYYYY format

what: Get available years for Nebraska enrollment data — get_available_years
title: Get available years for Nebraska enrollment data — get_available_years
text: Returns vector school year ends enrollment data available. Nebraska provides historical enrollment data 2002-03 present: 2018-present: CSV files (MembershipByGradeRaceAndGender) 2011-2017: TXT files current column format 2003-2010: TXT files legacy column format (pre-2010 race categories)

Get available years for Nebraska enrollment data — get_available_years
text: Integer vector available school year ends

title: Get available years for Nebraska enrollment data — get_available_years
text: Note: Years 2001-2002 (end_year 2002) earlier different data structures currently supported.

what: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: Downloads processes school data Nebraska Department Education. Provides functions fetching enrollment data NDE's public data reports transforming tidy format analysis.

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: fetch_enr Fetch enrollment data school year fetch_enr_multi Fetch enrollment data multiple years tidy_enr Transform wide data tidy (long) format id_enr_aggs Add aggregation level flags enr_grade_aggs Create grade-level aggregations get_available_years Get list available data years

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: cache_status View cached data files clear_cache Remove cached data files

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: Nebraska uses hierarchical ID system county-based codes: District IDs: County-District format (e.g., "55-0001" = Lincoln Public Schools) School IDs: County-District-School format (e.g., "55-0001-001") County codes: 2 digits (01-93) District codes: 4 digits School codes: 3 digits

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: Data sourced Nebraska Department Education's public reports: Data Reports: https://www.education.ne.gov/dataservices/data-reports/ Archives: https://www.education.ne.gov/dataservices/data-reports/data--information-archives/

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: Years: 2003-present (2002-03 school year onwards) Aggregation levels: State, District, School (Campus) Demographics: White, Black, Hispanic, Asian, Native American, Pacific Islander, Multiracial Gender: Male, Female Grade levels: PK, K, 01-12

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: years 2003-2010: Pacific Islander included Asian, Multiracial available years 2003-2005: Limited metadata (county information)

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: economically disadvantaged, LEP, special education data membership files Pre-2003 data different file formats (yet supported)

title: neschooldata: Fetch and Process Nebraska School Data — neschooldata-package
text: Maintainer: Al Martin almartin@example.com

title: Process school-level enrollment data — process_school_enr
text: Aggregates grade-level rows school totals standardizes column names. Handles three different column formats based data year: 2011+: Modern format separate Pacific Islander Multiracial 2006-2010: Legacy format combined Asian/Pacific Islander, Multiracial 2003-2005: Oldest format minimal columns
